facts.text: Appeals are C.A. Nos. 2132 and 2133 of 1970 by certificate from judgment and order dated June 22, 1965 of Calcutta High Court in I.T. Reference No. 36 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. Nos. 2132 and 2133 of 1970. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated June 22, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in I.T. Reference No. 36 of 1961. Sukumar Mitra J.

facts.text: Assessee Guzdar Kajora Coal Mines Ltd. was incorporated on July 4, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The assesses Guzdar Kajora Coal Mines Ltd. which was incorporated on July 4, 1945 purchased by a deed of companyvey- ance dated April 3, 1966 executed by the liquidators of Guzdar Kajora Colliery Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Assessee purchased all colliery lands, hereditaments, premises, mines, minerals, powers, privileges, machinery etc. from liquidators of Guzdar Kajora Colliery Co. Ltd. by deed dated April 3, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The assesses Guzdar Kajora Coal Mines Ltd. which was incorporated on July 4, 1945 purchased by a deed of companyvey- ance dated April 3, 1966 executed by the liquidators of Guzdar Kajora Colliery Co. Ltd. all the companyliery lands, hereditaments and premises, mines, minerals, powers and privileges and all ,other hereditaments together with the machinery thereon belonging to the latter companypany.

facts.text: Sale effective from July 1, 1945 as stipulated in deed of conveyance.

anchor.surface_text: It was stipulated in the deed of ,conveyance that the sale was to be effective from July 1, 1945. The companysideration for the transfer was Rs. 6 lacs and was allocated as follows -

facts.text: Consideration for transfer was Rs. 6 lacs allocated as: machinery plants stores Rs. 3,50,000; buildings Rs. 1,50,000; rest of properties Rs. 1,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: The companysideration for the transfer was Rs. 6 lacs and was allocated as follows -  a  the value of the machinery plants stores including stock of goods grains companyls at the pithead and other movable properties appertaining to the said companyliery the property in which is capable of passing by delivery being Rs. 3,50,000/-.  b  the value of the buildings and structures be longing to the said companyliery being Rs. 1,50,000/-.  c  the value of the rest of the properties appertaining, to the said companyliery number capable of being passed by delivery being Rs. 1,00,000/-

facts.text: Assessee took over business from vendor soon after coming into existence and claimed depreciation for 1946-47 on basis of figures in statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after the assessee companypany came into existence it took over the business from the vendor companypany and claimed depre- ciation for the assessment year 1946-47 on the basis of, the figures the companyparative statement of which is given in the statement of the case.

facts.text: Income tax Officer allowed depreciation on basis of vendor's written down value, balance sheet etc. for years up to 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: This statement companytains the written down value as per the assessment record of the vendor companypany the valuation of the assets as per the balance sheet of the vendor companypany and the valuation by the assessee companypany as per balance sheet as on December 30, 1945. The Income tax Officer allowed depreciation on the basis of those figures. This state of affairs companytinued till the assessment year 1952-53

facts.text: For 1952-53 and 1953-54, assessee contended before AAC that depreciation should be on basis of balance sheet valuation as per audited accounts.

anchor.surface_text: when the Income tax Officer again allowed depreciation on the old basis. Before, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner the assessee raised a ground ,that the Income tax Officer should. have worked ,out the depreciation figures on the basis of balance sheet valuation of the assets as per the audited accounts submitted by the assessee and as claimed in the return.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Income tax Appellate Tribunal after failing before AAC.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Income tax Appellate Tribunal, having failed in its companytentions before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Before ITAT, assessee contended that Rs. 6 lacs paid but depreciation on lower value, hardship, based on expert opinion.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended before the Appellate Tribunal by the assessee that although it had paid a sum of Rs. 6 lacs as companysideration for the transfer of the mines the value taken by the department for the purpose of determining depreciation Was much lower. It was pointed out that the purchase had been made after obtaining, the opinion of an expert

facts.text: ITAT remanded to ITO for inquiry on value paid, opportunity to assessee, for 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal was of the view that substantial injustice would result to the assessee if the depreciation companytinued to be allowed on the old basis if the case of the assessee had any substance. It was felt that a proper investigation as to the value paid by the assessee in taking over the old companypany was necessary. The matter was remanded to the Income-tax Officer

facts.text: ITO made report on July 6, 1960 finding common directors/shareholders, valuations written up for depreciable assets and down for non-depreciable.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer made a report on July 6, 1960. According to his findings some of the Directors and Shareholders of the two companypanies were the same and they were companynected in many ways. Furthermore the valuation of the depreciable assets and the companysumable stores had been written up whereas the valuation of the number-depreciable assets like mines etc. had been written down.

facts.text: Expert A. N. Mitter report dated September 1, 1945; ITO unable to contact him.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the report of the expert A. N. Mitter dated September 1, 1945 he was unable to companytact him in spite of making an effort to do so.

facts.text: Expert S. N. Mullick reports dated October 19, 1955, January 30, 1957, clarification November 20, 1959; examined under S.37.

anchor.surface_text: The report made by the second expert S. N. Mullick dated October 19, 1955 and January 30, 1957 together with the clarification made by him on November 20, 1959 were companysidered by him. He also examined 8. N. Mullick under S. 37 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: ITO concluded vendor making profits but no provision for goodwill Rs. 2,56,960 based on preceding 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: He came to the companyclusion that the vendor had been making good profits but numberprovision had been made for the goodwill of the companypany in the business and if such a provision had been made it would have worked out at Rs. 2,56,960/- having regard to the profits made for the preceding four years.

facts.text: ITO allocated Rs. 6 lacs: Goodwill Rs. 2,56,960; Mines Rs.2,48,323; Stores Rs.60,744; other depreciable Rs. 33,973.

anchor.surface_text: He made an allocation of Rs. 6 lacs as follows Good-will Rs. 2,56,960/- Mines and development as per balance-sheet of M s. Guzdar Gajore Colliery Co. Ltd. as at 30-6-45. Rs.2,48,323/- Stores and stock Rs.60,744/- and worked out the value of other depreciable assets at Rs. 33,973/-

facts.text: ITAT dismissed assessee's appeals, held figures in deed arbitrary, no clear breakup, goodwill not in Rs.1,00,000 clause.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us, the simple truth of the matter is that the figure of Rs. 3,50,000/-, Rs. 1,50,000/- and Rs. 1,00,000/- were arbitrarily put. and there was numberclear cut or understandable break up of valuation  ?  clause 3 of the break up in the deed of 3rd April 1946, which talks of the value of the rest of the properties

facts.text: ITAT referred question to High Court: Whether ITO competent to go beyond conveyance and fix valuation.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee moved the Tribunal for referring certain questions of law to the Tribunal. The following question was framed by the Tribunal and referred to the High Court Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Income-tax Officer was companypetent to go beyond the companyveyance

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held ITO competent to make fresh computation if justified, agreed with findings on goodwill etc.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the Income-tax Officer was companypetent to make a fresh companyputation as to the value of the assets of the assessee if the facts and circumstances of a particular case justified following such a companyrse. Even on the question of valuation of the good-will ... The revenue has. examined all the relevant facts of the case including the reports of Mr. Mitter and Mr. Mullick and the Tribunal has agreed with those findings of facts

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals, however, must fail for the reasons stated earlier and are hereby dismissed. We make numberorder as to companyts in this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 2   vi  of the Act, to the extent it is material is as follows Such profits or gains shall be computed after making the following allowances, namely- in respect of depreciation of such buildings machinery, plant or furniture being the property of the assessee, a sum equivalent, where the assets are ships other than ships ordinarily plying on inland waters, to such percentage on the original cost thereof to the assessee as may in any case or class of cases be prescribed and in any other case, to such percentage on the written down value thereof as may in any case ,or class of cases be prescribed-------------- Provided that--  a   b  The aggregate of all allowances in res- pect of depreciation made under this clause and clause  vi-a  or under any Act repealed hereby, or under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1886  II of 1886 , shall, in no case exceed the original cost to the assessee of the buildings, machinery, plant or furniture, as the case may be

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer was competent to go beyond the conveyance and fix a valuation of the assets on his own on the facts and circumstances of the case.

anchor.surface_text: The following question was framed by the Tribunal and referred to the High Court Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Income-tax Officer was competent to go beyond the conveyance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court and Tribunal findings that facts justified fresh computation due to common directors/shareholders, arbitrary allocations, and expert reports indicating inflated depreciable assets.

holdings.text: The original actual cost to the assessee of the asset has to be ascertained for the purpose of depreciation allowance and written down value.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping in view sub-s. 5 of S. 10 of the Act, the original actual cost to the assessee of the asset with regard to which depreciation allowance is claimed has to be ascertained for the purpose inter-alia

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in Buckingham & Carnatic and this Court's Jogta Coal; depreciation based on cost to current assessee, not previous owner.

holdings.text: A formal deed of conveyance mentioning consideration is prima facie evidence of cost to assessee, but Income-tax authorities may refuse it and ascertain actual cost if circumstances show fictitious price, fraud, collusion, or inflation/deflation for ulterior purposes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualifies prima facie rule with exceptions from precedents (Pindi Kashmir Transport, Kalooram Govindram); applies to facts of common connections and arbitrary valuations.

holdings.text: It is open to Income-tax authorities to determine whether goodwill is included in consideration even if not expressly mentioned, ascertainable by evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence can show inclusion despite omission in deed; references Cambatta case explanation of goodwill; facts showed no provision despite profits.

holdings.text: If circumstances exist for going behind the valuation and allocation in the deed, Income-tax authorities may determine valuation and allocation between depreciable and non-depreciable assets.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies to case facts of suspicious allocations (depreciable up, non-depreciable down) and ITO/Tribunal/High Court findings upheld.

holdings.text: Decision of Tribunal or High Court does not operate as res judicata for other pending assessment years; assessee entitled to raise valuation points for depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: could not operate as res judicata for other assessment years with regard to which assessments are still pending, the assessee would be entitled to raise all the points which are relevant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter guidance; agrees with assessee contention as pressed, for future assessments.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals, however, must fail for the reasons stated earlier and are hereby dismissed. We make no order as to costs in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No error in lower courts' application to facts; upholds competence and valuations including goodwill.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income tax, Madras v. The Buckingham and Carnatic Co., Ltd. Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income tax, Madras v. The Buckingham and Carnatic Co., Ltd. Madras 1 , that the word assessee in s. 10 2  vi  of the Act refers to the person who owns the assets and who is being assessed and depreciation allowance has to be based on the original companysideration of such property to such person.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: the word assessee in s. 10(2)(vi) of the Act refers to the person who owns the assets and who is being assessed and depreciation allowance has to be based on the original cost of such property to such person
precedents.cited_holding: depreciation allowance has to be based on the original cost of such property to such person

precedents.citation: Jogta Coal Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Jogta Coal Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax West Bengal 1  and it was observed We do number think that there is any doubt on the wording of the section or on the interpretation that has been put upon those words that the companysideration to be calculated for the purpose of depreciation allowance is the companysideration to the assessee and number to the person who makes the sale

precedents.case_name: Jogta Coal Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: the cost to be calculated for the purpose of depreciation allowance is the cost to the assessee and not to the person who makes the sale
precedents.cited_holding: there is no doubt on the wording of the section or on the interpretation that has been put upon those words that the cost to be calculated for the purpose of depreciation allowance is the cost to the assessee and not to the person who makes the sale

precedents.citation: Pindi Kashmir Transport Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax Lahore  2

anchor.surface_text: Pindi Kashmir Transport Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax Lahore  2   and Kalooram Govindram v. Commissioner of Income tax Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur and Bhandara 3 . In this view of the matter it is open to the Income tax authorities to determine and to the assessee to show. whether the good-will of the business is or is number included in the companysideration or the price paid for the acquisition of the asset.

precedents.case_name: Pindi Kashmir Transport Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Lahore
precedents.cited_proposition: if circumstances exist showing that a fictitious price has been put on the asset or there is fraud or collusion between the vendor and the vendee and there has been inflation or deflation-of-value for ulterior purposes it is open to the Income tax authorities to refuse to accept the price mentioned in the deed or alleged by the assessee and to ascertain what the actual cost was

precedents.citation: Kalooram Govindram v. Commissioner of Income tax Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur and Bhandara 3

anchor.surface_text: Kalooram Govindram v. Commissioner of Income tax Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur and Bhandara 3 . In this view of the matter it is open to the Income tax authorities to determine and to the assessee to show. whether the good-will of the business is or is number included in the companysideration or the price paid for the acquisition of the asset. In other words even if it is number expressly mentioned that goodwill has been sold it can be shown and ascertained by evidence whether the same has been purchased or number by the assessee.

precedents.case_name: Kalooram Govindram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur and Bhandara
precedents.cited_proposition: if circumstances exist showing that a fictitious price has been put on the asset or there is fraud or collusion between the vendor and the vendee and there has been inflation or deflation-of-value for ulterior purposes it is open to the Income tax authorities to refuse to accept the price mentioned in the deed or alleged by the assessee and to ascertain what the actual cost was

precedents.citation: S. C. Cambatta Co. P. Ltd. v. Commissioner Excess Profits Tax, Bombay 4

anchor.surface_text: S. C. Cambatta Co. P. Ltd. v. Commissioner Excess Profits Tax, Bombay 4  and numberhing more need be said about it. The principles stated by us are by numbermeans exhaustive and are mainly illustrative. Keeping in view the facts of the present case we may make it clear that if circumstances exist for going behind the valuation as also the allocation given in the deed of companyveyance it was and is open to the Income tax authorities to determine the valuation as well as the allocation between depreciable and number-depreciable assets.
